ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about anthropological study and human evolution.
For sure the most useful skills I took away from this class were how to research or how to structure research papers. As for the actual content... nah.

I developed a better understanding of how to read and analyze scientific literature. I learned how to interpret the morphology of various hominids and their implications for the specimen as a whole. I also learned more about the field of paleoanthropology.
I learned about the lines of evidence used to solidify scientific discoveries in human evolution and how to be skeptical of those evidence when presented with new discoveries.

I developed knowledge about the anthropological field and the old and recent discoveries. I had very limited prior knowledge but now have a good understanding of the basic concepts, discoveries, and methods used. I also learned how to use Zotero to create an annotated bibliography.
I gained some knowledge in the field of anthropology and a lot of what it entails to do research in such an area.

I learned a lot about reading and skimming scholarly articles. The reality of it is no one has time to read every article published, so pulling out the main information from a 20 page article is a useful skill to have, and I learned that in this class for sure, among other skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class format was more lecture-oriented than a seminar, so I would've liked more class discussions. Nonetheless, the content covered was very interesting and engaging.

The course felt all over the place at times. I wish the professor would have a more set lesson plan, because when almost every class started with a list of four or five activities that we "could do", the less enthusiastic members of class really just defaulted to whatever was the easiest (and often least interesting).

I really liked that this course was structured in a more relaxed manner in terms of day to day seminars: we could spend an entire seminar just asking questions about the readings or what we had learned so far, or we could do a lecture about new material instead. I feel like this flexibility really maximized my learning for the course.
I enjoyed how hands on the course was but it sometimes felt more like a lecture than a seminar.

The strengths are the staged assignments, activities, and debates really help you dive into the material and learn independently. The weaknesses are besides these activities, classes were structured more like lectures whereas I would have hoped for more seminar based classes and discussions.

The strengths were that the professor was an expert and had experience with a lot of the material we discussed in class. The weaknesses were how difficult it was to engage with such dense material that wasnt easily understood a lot of the time.

I really enjoyed the structure of the class, the readings went well with the lectures. I do think one weakness of the course was how many of the classes were lecture style, and less seminar (this may have been due, however, to the lack of engagement from my peers). I absolutely loved the debates, and making our own stone tools to showcase how difficult it actually is was a great hands-on way to learn about the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. This course provided a very interesting overview of major events and processes of human evolution, how the information was discovered, and how the field continues to evolve.

If you've come to Yale specifically interested in Prof. Thompson's work, then I could definitely recommend this course, as she absolutely facilitates introductions into her lab or summer projects for the most interested students. If you're looking for a gut social science credit with a fair amount of biology, I'd also recommend it (with an asterisk). Elsewise, I wouldn't.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in anthropology! It was incredibly engaging and flexible to what we were curious about in the field.
I would recommend this course to another student, but only if they have interest in Anthropology.
If you are interested in anthropology, I would recommend it. However, it's not the best use of your time if you don't love the subject or aren't that interested in it.

I would not recommend this course to another student. The description advertised as something more interesting in my opinion. If paleo anthropology is your interest then it could be for you. I just felt that for a seminar, it was heavy on lectures and the assignments didnt feel engaging with what we had talked about in class a lot.

It is definitely a niche subject in terms of areas of study, so I would recommend with caution. I was not extremely interested in the study of human origins initially, but my interest grew over time. Overall, I would recommend it, but almost all students would be starting from scratch.
